articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(Nature) - Last month saw a major landmark for regenerative medicine: the
first time that a stem-cell therapy — beside the use of cells extracted from
umbilical cords — had been cleared for sale by any regulatory agency in the …
Read More
articles.title: Behind the Scenes of the World’s First Commercial Stem-Cell Therapy (bioethicscom)

articles.author: Washington Post: None Given
articles.summary:
Washington Post: Not long ago, scientists at NASA and two major universities
warned of an inevitable “megadrought” that will parch the southwestern United
States for 35 years, starting around 2050. By then, a new study says,
Californians should be fairly accustomed to long, harsh and dry conditions.
Over the past 15 years, temperatures have been rising in the Golden State,
resulting in annual periods of extreme and blazing heat, while the cycle of
low and moderate precipitation cycles have not changed since 1977....
articles.title: California’s terrifying forecast: In future, it could face droughts nearly every year (climateark)

articles.author: By ANDREW C. REVKIN
articles.summary:
Without tougher enforcement of fishing rules, time will soon run out for
Mexico’s vaquita, the world’s smallest cetacean.
articles.title: Dot Earth Blog: Two Minutes to Midnight for the World’s Tiniest Cetacean – Mexico’s Vaquita (NY Times)

A process for catalytically converting crude tall oil into hydrocarbons
suitable as biofuel components. The crude tall oil is treated in a reactor
system including a catalytically active guard bed phase and a catalytically
active main reaction phase. At least one of the phases includes a catalyst bed
with a...
articles.title: Process for producing biofuel and biofuel components (Fresh Patents)

articles.author: Agata Blaszczak Boxe, LiveScience
articles.summary:
Two gorgeous new species of peacock spiders nicknamed 'Skeletorus' and
'Sparklemuffin' have been discovered in Australia.
articles.title: 'Skeletorus' and 'Sparklemuffin' the Newest Spiders (Discovery)

articles.summary:
A Swiss teenager, recently returned home from a discotheque, came to the
emergency department with classic sudden symptoms of stroke, only to be
diagnosed with Lyme disease. The highly unusual case presentation was
published online last Thursday in Annals of Emergency Medicine.
articles.title: Teenager with stroke symptoms actually had Lyme disease (Eurekalert)

articles.summary:
The queen bee in this image is marked with a green dot. Researchers from North
Carolina State University, Indiana University and Wellesley College have
characterized the gut microbiome of honey bee queens. This is the first
thorough census of the gut microbiome - which consists of all the
microorganisms that live in the gut of the organism - in queen bees.
articles.title: The environment may change, but the microbiome of queen bees does not (Biologynews)

articles.summary:

there was nothing new under the Sun (or Moon, as it were) when it comes to new
unofficial lunar terminology. Sure, the Moon now seems more colorful than
controversial viral dress shades. Love it or loathe it, the Internet can sure
set […]
articles.title: The Mini-Moon Cometh: Catch the Smallest Full Moon of 2015 This Thursday (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
Let's say you're a small cell engaged in heavy manufacturing. Like most animal
cells, you are coated only in a thin membrane made a double layer of fluid
fat-like molecules.

articles.title: Tiny Cell Grows Giant Death Spike and Lives to Grow Another (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
Saturn's moon Titan is too cold for cell membranes to form as they do on
Earth. But researchers have come up with a cell membrane that could exist on
Titan. Christopher Intagliata reports.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Titan Could Host Life 'Not As We Know It' (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
(Reuters) - A little known but controversial program that flagged sensitive
patent applications involving potentially touchy subjects such as AIDS
vaccines and abortion devices has been scrapped by the United States Patent
and Trademark Office.
articles.title: U.S. ends program flagging 'sensitive' patent requests (reuters)
